Next, employ the method of returning the elixir. As before, thrust the chest forward and stretch the waist, close the double gates of the spine, then crouch and extend. If the fire in the waist does not rise, sit in stillness and inwardly observe. Repeat the method until the fire arises to the required degree. Begin at the *chou* hour and continue until the end of the *yin* hour, at which point one may stop. This is called "flying golden essence behind the elbows," also known as "drawing lead," whereby the qi of the kidneys generates the qi of the liver.

Moreover, the human spine consists of twenty-four vertebrae. From the bottom upward, the first three correspond to the internal kidneys. From the top downward, the first three are called the "Pillar of Heaven." Above the Pillar of Heaven lies the "Jade Capital." Below the Pillar of Heaven, opposite the internal kidneys and above the *Weilü* point, are eighteen vertebrae. Among these, the middle section is called the "double gates," with nine above and nine below. One must stabilize for one hundred days until the qi traverses all eighteen vertebrae and enters the *Niwan* palace. This must be practiced during the first yang hour, under the *Kan* trigram. This is called "flying golden essence behind the elbows." Under the *Li* trigram, one gathers the medicine; under the *Qian* trigram, one advances the fire to refine the medicine and restrains the yang gate. Only then, after one hundred days, does the golden essence fly into the brain. With a single thrust through the three gates, it enters the upper palace of *Niwan*.

Beginning with the *Kan* trigram, the practice continues until the *Gen* trigram. Under the *Li* trigram, one gathers the medicine, uniting the qi of the heart and kidneys, whereby the qi of the liver naturally arises from the qi of the heart. When the two qi become purely yang, the two eights of yin dissolve. Steaming upward into the lungs, the lung fluid descends, enveloping the true qi. Daily, a grain of millet in size enters the Yellow Court—this is called the material of the inner elixir. Only after one hundred days without error is the medicinal power complete.

When gathering medicine under the *Li* trigram, observe the timing inwardly with even greater precision. When advancing the fire under the *Qian* trigram to refine the medicine and restrain the yang gate, begin at the *Dui* trigram and conclude at the *Qian* trigram. Thus, for another one hundred days, the golden essence flies behind the elbows, starting at the *Kan* trigram and ending at the *Zhen* trigram. During the time of gathering medicine under the *Li* trigram, follow the previous method, practicing from the *Kun* to the *Qian* trigram. After two hundred days without error, the sacred embryo becomes firm.

The method of restraining the yang gate concludes at the *Qian* trigram. After another one hundred days, the *Niwan* palace is fully replenished, and one reverts from old age to youth, no longer resembling ordinary people. Once the medicine is gathered and the embryo immortal is complete, true qi arises, its form like a round pellet, its color like a red tangerine. It permanently resides in the cinnabar field, and one becomes an immortal of the earthly realm.

After three hundred days of practice, cease gathering medicine under the *Li* trigram and restraining the yang gate under the *Kun* trigram. Then proceed with the method of returning the jade fluid elixir. Thus, only after the winter solstice does one begin the practice. After three hundred days, the embryo is complete, the qi is full, and the inner elixir is achieved, with true qi generated.

This method is the inversion of the Five Phases and the reversal of the Three Fields. Before practicing, one must first harmonize yin and yang, ensuring the mutual generation of qi and fluid, and continue until verification is achieved. Next, gather and disperse water and fire, solidifying the root source until the qi moves and the fluid stabilizes, and verification is achieved. Then, unite the dragon and tiger, refining the elixir medicine, gathering and replenishing the returning elixir, and forging lead and mercury until verification is achieved. When the count of "ten depletions and one replenishment" is fulfilled, and the mutual generation of qi and fluid is verified, one may proceed.

The above practice is a method of the Lesser Vehicle, sufficient for prolonging life and extending years. Only after replenishment is complete and firmness is verified may one select a month in the year—specifically the winter solstice—and a day in the month—specifically the *jiazi* day—and an hour in the day—specifically the hours of the *Kan*, *Li*, and *Qian* trigrams—to begin. For the first one hundred days, proceed from *Kan* to *Gen* and from *Dui* to *Qian*. After two hundred days, proceed from *Kan* to *Zhen* and from *Kun* to *Qian*.

All such practice must be conducted in a secluded chamber within a tranquil dwelling, far from women and girls, ensuring that the sounds of chickens and dogs are unheard, foul odors do not enter the nose, the five flavors do not pass the lips, and the seven emotions and six desires are severed. Regulate the quantity of food and drink, and maintain moderation in cold and heat. Even in sleep, one must remain vigilant against loss or damage. Without diligent practice, the Dao is difficult to achieve. After three hundred days, observe the results.

The true explanation states: This is the method of the Three Origins. Under the *Kan* trigram, the golden essence flies—this is the lower field returning to the upper field. Under the *Li* trigram, the medicine is gathered—this is the lower field returning to the middle field. Under the *Qian* trigram, the yang gate is restrained—this is the middle returning to the lower. This is also called the reversal of the Three Fields.

*The Essentials of the Dao* states: "The sun and moon move together under the *Fu* trigram; crouch and rise for several days to open the gates. Greedily gather in Yangzhou; the six palaces are filled with fire in the golden field."

The explanation states: "The sun and moon moving together under the *Fu* trigram" refers to the time when the first yang arises—at the *zi* hour in the day and the winter solstice in the year. This is what is meant by selecting a day in the month and an hour in the day. "Crouch and rise" has been explained previously. "Several days" refers to the fixed one hundred days. "Opening the gates" means first opening the middle gate, then the upper gate. "Greedily gathering in Yangzhou"—Yangzhou corresponds to the heart in the human body, the *wu* hour in the day, and the *Li* trigram. "Gathering" refers to the union of true yin and true yang, hence the gathering of medicine. *Qian* represents the six palaces, and fire is qi. By restraining the yang gate and gathering qi, the lung qi is metal, descending to the kidney’s cinnabar field. Thus, "the six palaces are filled with fire in the golden field" refers to practicing under the *Qian* trigram to restrain the yang gate, gathering fire in the lower cinnabar field.

The direct explanation states: "The sun and moon moving together under the *Fu* trigram" refers to the hour of *jiazi* at the winter solstice. "Crouch and rise for several days to open the gates" means crouching the abdomen and rising the body to kindle the fire, opening the gates after one hundred days. This is the method of flying golden essence from *Kan* to *Gen*. "Gathering in Yangzhou" refers to the union of yin and yang under the *Li* trigram to gather medicine. "The six palaces are filled with fire in the golden field" refers to restraining the yang gate under the *Qian* trigram, gathering lung qi in the lower field—this is the practice from *Dui* to *Qian*.

chunks.original_text: 终南路上逢山，升身频过三关。 贪向扬州聚会，争如少女烧天。 解曰：终南者，圣人隐意在中男也，中男即坎卦。 良为山，山是势，飞金晶至巽卦方止，第二百日下功之时也。 升身频过三关、贪向扬州聚会，说已在前。 争如少女烧天者，少女是兑卦也，勒阳关至乾卦而方止也。 兖克州行到徐州，起来走损车牛。 为恋九州欢会，西南火入雍州。 解曰：艮州，艮卦； 徐州，巽卦。 自艮卦飞金晶，至巽卦方止也。 起来走损车牛，车为阳，牛为阴，“是夹脊一气飞入泥丸也。 九州，在人为心，在日为午时，与前来药园也。 西南，坤卦也。 雍州，乾卦也。 勒阳关，自坤至乾方止，第三百日下功之时也。 直解曰：此乃第三百日之功，飞金晶之法，起艮而止巽也。 九州欢会，采药如前。 勒阳关； 则自坤至乾酉止也。 此是日用事，乃日三元用法。 飞金晶入脑，下田返上田； 采药，下田返中田； 烧药进火，中田返下田：乃曰三元用事。 中乘之法，已是地仙，见验方止。 始觉梦寐多有惊悸，四肢六腑有疾，不疗自愈，闭目暗室中，圆光如盖，周匝围身，金关玉锁，封固坚牢，绝梦泄遗漏，雷鸣一声，关节气通，梦寐若抱婴儿归，或若飞腾自在，八邪之气不能入，心境自除，以绝情欲，内观则朗而不昧，昼则神采清秀，夜则丹田自暖，上件皆是得药之验。 改既正当，谨节用功，以前法加添三百日胎仙圆，胎圆之后，方用后功。 玉液还丹第六附玉液炼形 《玉书》曰：真阴真阳，相生相成； 见于上者，积阳成神，神中有形而丽乎天者，日月也； 见于下者，积阴成形，形中有形而丽平地者，金玉也。 金玉之质； 隐于山川秀媚之气，浮之于上，与日月交光，草木受之以为祯祥，鸟兽得之以为异类。 《真源》曰：阳升到天，太极生阴，阴不足而阳有徐，所以积阳生神； 阴降到地，太极生阳，阳不足而阴有馀，所以积阴生形。 上之日月，下之金玉，真阳有神，真阴有形，其气相交，而上下相射，光盈天地，则金玉可贵者，良以此也。 是知金玉之气凝于空，则为瑞气祥烟，入于地； 则变醴泉芝草，人民受之而为英杰，鸟兽得之而生奇异。 盖金玉之质，虽产于积阴之形； 而中抱真阳之气，又感积阳成神之日月，真阳之下射而宝凝矣。 《比喻》曰：积阴成形，而内抱真阳，以为金玉，比为金玉，比于积药而抱真气，以为胎仙也。 金玉之气入于地，而为醴泉芝草者，比于玉液还丹田也。 金玉之气凝于空，而为瑞气样烟者，比于气炼形质也。 凡金玉之气冲于天，随阳升而起，凡金玉之气入于地，随阴降而还，既随阴阳升降，自有四时，可以液还丹田，气炼形质，比于四时加减，一日改移也 《真诀》曰：采补见验，年中择月； 月中择日，日中择时，三时用事，一百日药力全，二百日圣胎坚，三百日真气生，胎仙圆。 谨节用功，加添依时，三百日数足之后，方行还丹炼形之法。 凡用艮卦飞金晶入脑，止于巽卦而白，此言飞金晶三百日后也。 离封罢采药，坤卦罢勒阳关，只此兑卦下手，勒阳关，至乾封方止。 既罢离卦，添入咽法炼形。 咽法者，以舌搅上腭两凳之间，先咽了恶浊之津，次退舌尖以满玉池，津生不漱而咽。 凡春三月，肝气旺而脾气弱，咽法日用离卦；

On the road to Zhongnan, mountains are met—
rising the body to repeatedly pass the Three Passes.
Greedily seeking union in Yangzhou,
how could it compare to the maiden burning heaven?

Explanation states: *Zhongnan* refers to the Sage’s hidden meaning in the *Middle Son*—the *Middle Son* being the *Kan* trigram. *Gen* is mountain, and mountain is power; the flying golden essence halts only upon reaching the *Xun* trigram—this is the time of the second hundred days of practice. "Rising the body to repeatedly pass the Three Passes" and "greedily seeking union in Yangzhou" have been explained previously. "How could it compare to the maiden burning heaven?"—the *maiden* is the *Dui* trigram, and restraining the yang gate halts only upon reaching the *Qian* trigram.

From Yanzhou to Xuzhou,
rising to walk wears out cart and ox.
For the sake of delighting in the Nine Provinces’ union,
fire enters Yongzhou in the southwest.

Explanation states: *Genzhou* is the *Gen* trigram; *Xuzhou* is the *Xun* trigram. Flying golden essence from the *Gen* trigram halts only upon reaching the *Xun* trigram. "Rising to walk wears out cart and ox"—the *cart* is yang, the *ox* is yin; this is the qi of the spine flying into the *Mud Pill*. The *Nine Provinces* correspond in man to the heart, and in time to the hour of *wu*—this is the medicine garden previously mentioned. The *southwest* is the *Kun* trigram; *Yongzhou* is the *Qian* trigram. Restraining the yang gate halts only upon reaching *Qian*—this is the time of the third hundred days of practice.

Direct explanation states: This is the method of flying golden essence for the third hundred days, rising from *Gen* and halting at *Xun*. The union of the Nine Provinces is the gathering of medicine as before. Restraining the yang gate halts only upon reaching *you* in *Qian*. This is the daily practice, the method of the Three Primordials. Flying golden essence into the brain returns the lower field to the upper field; gathering medicine returns the lower field to the middle field; burning medicine and advancing fire returns the middle field to the lower field—this is called the practice of the Three Primordials. The method of the Middle Vehicle is already that of an Earth Immortal, and practice ceases only upon verification. One first notices that dreams are often startled and fearful, the four limbs and six viscera afflicted with illness, yet they heal without treatment. In a dark room with eyes closed, a radiant light like a canopy encircles the body; the golden gate and jade lock seal firmly, cutting off dream emissions and leakage. With a thunderous roar, the qi of the joints flows freely, and in dreams one may hold an infant in return or soar freely at will. The eight perverse qi cannot enter, the heart’s illusions vanish, and desires are extinguished. Inward contemplation is bright and unobscured; by day, the spirit’s countenance is clear and refined; by night, the cinnabar field is naturally warm. All these are signs of obtaining the medicine. Once the correction is proper, practice diligently with care, adding three hundred days to the previous method to complete the *Fetal Immortal*. Only after the fetal completion does one proceed to the subsequent practice.

**Sixth: Jade Fluid Returning to the Cinnabar—Appendix on Jade Fluid Refining the Form**

*The Jade Book* states: True yin and true yang mutually generate and complete one another. That which appears above is accumulated yang forming spirit; within spirit there is form, and that which adheres to heaven is the sun and moon. That which appears below is accumulated yin forming shape; within shape there is form, and that which adheres to earth is gold and jade. The essence of gold and jade is concealed within the elegant qi of mountains and rivers, floating above to exchange radiance with the sun and moon. Plants and trees receive it to become auspicious omens, birds and beasts obtain it to become extraordinary species.

*The True Source* states: When yang ascends to heaven, the Supreme Ultimate generates yin; yin is insufficient while yang has surplus, thus accumulated yang generates spirit. When yin descends to earth, the Supreme Ultimate generates yang; yang is insufficient while yin has surplus, thus accumulated yin generates shape. Above, the sun and moon; below, gold and jade—true yang has spirit, true yin has form. Their qi intermingle, and above and below reflect one another; light fills heaven and earth, and thus gold and jade are precious. It is known that when the qi of gold and jade congeals in the void, it becomes auspicious qi and propitious mist; when it enters the earth, it transforms into sweet springs and magic herbs. People receive it to become heroes, birds and beasts obtain it to produce marvels. Though the essence of gold and jade is produced from accumulated yin’s shape, it embraces the qi of true yang and is further moved by the sun and moon formed from accumulated yang’s spirit. True yang’s downward reflection causes treasure to congeal.

*The Analogy* states: Accumulated yin forms shape yet inwardly embraces true yang to become gold and jade—this is analogous to accumulating medicine and embracing true qi to become a *Fetal Immortal*. When the qi of gold and jade enters the earth to become sweet springs and magic herbs, it is analogous to jade fluid returning to the cinnabar field. When the qi of gold and jade congeals in the void to become auspicious qi and propitious mist, it is analogous to qi refining the form. Whenever the qi of gold and jade surges into the heavens, it rises with yang; whenever it enters the earth, it descends with yin. Since it follows the ascent and descent of yin and yang, it naturally has the four seasons. Thus, one may return fluid to the cinnabar field and refine the form with qi, analogous to the four seasons’ waxing and waning and the daily transformations.

*The True Formula* states: For gathering and supplementing, verification is sought within the year; within the month, the day is chosen; within the day, the hour is selected. Practicing the Three Primordials for one hundred days, the medicine’s power is complete; for two hundred days, the sacred fetus is firm; for three hundred days, true qi is born, and the *Fetal Immortal* is complete. Practice diligently with care, adding time as appropriate. Only after the full three hundred days does one proceed to the method of returning the cinnabar and refining the form. Whenever using the *Gen* trigram to fly golden essence into the brain, it halts at the *Xun* trigram and ceases—this refers to flying golden essence after three hundred days. The *Li* trigram ceases gathering medicine; the *Kun* trigram ceases restraining the yang gate. Only the *Dui* trigram is employed, restraining the yang gate until it halts at the *Qian* trigram’s seal. Having ceased the *Li* trigram, the swallowing method for refining the form is added.

The swallowing method: With the tongue, stir between the upper palate and the two ridges, first swallowing the foul and turbid fluid, then retracting the tongue’s tip to fill the Jade Pool. The fluid is generated, not rinsed, and swallowed. In the three months of spring, when liver qi is flourishing and spleen qi is weak, the swallowing method is practiced daily under the *Li* trigram.

chunks.original_text: 凡耀三月，心气旺而肺气弱，咽法日用巽卦； 凡秋三月，肺气旺而胖气弱； 咽法日用艮卦； 凡冬三月，肾气旺而心气弱。 咽法日用震卦，凡四季之月，脾气旺而肾气弱，人以肾气为根源，四时皆有衷弱，每四时季月之后十八日，咽法日用兑封，仍与前咽法并用之； 独于秋季止用兑卦咽法，而罢艮卦之功。 以上咽法，先依前法而咽之。 如牙齿玉池之间而津不生，但以舌满上下而闭玉池、收两颌，以虚咽而为法，止于咽气，气中自有水也。 咽气如一年，三十六次至四十九次为数； 又次一年，八十一次； 又次一年，一百八十一次为见验：乃主液还丹之法。 行持不过三年； 灌溉丹田，沐浴胎仙，而真气愈盛。 若行此，玉液还丹之法，而于三百日养就内丹，真气才生，艮卦飞金晶，一撞三关，上至泥丸，当行金掖还丹之法自顶中前下金水一注，下还黄庭，变金成丹，名曰金丹。 行金液还丹，当于深密幽房，风日凡人不到之处，烧香，叠掌盘膝坐，以体蹲而后升，才觉火起，正坐绝念，忘情内观，的确艮卦飞金晶入顶，但略昂头偃项，放令颈下如火，方点头向前，低头曲项； 退舌央进后以抵上腭，上有清洽之水，味若甘香，上彻项门，下遗百脉，鼻中自闻一种真香，舌上亦有奇味； 不漱而咽，下还黄庭，名曰金液还丹。 春夏秋冬，不拘时候，但于飞金晶入脑之后，节次行此法，自艮至巽而已； 晚间勒阳关法，自兑至乾而已。 凡行此法，谨节胜前，方可得成，究竟止于炼形住世，长生不死而已，不能超脱也。 《道要》曰：识取五行根蒂，方知春夏冬秋。 时饮琼浆数盏，醉归月殿邀游。 解曰：识取五行根蒂者，为倒五行相生相克，而用卦时不同，以行咽法。 方知春夏冬秋，改移有时候也。 琼浆，玉液也。 月殿，丹田也。 醉归，咽多也。 东望扶桑未晓，后升前咽无休。 骤马邀游宇宙，长男只到扬州。 解曰：东望扶桑未晓者，日未出，艮卦之时也。 后升，飞金晶也。 前咽，玉液还丹也。 骤马，起火，玉液炼形也。 邀游宇宙，遍满四肢也。 长男，震卦也。 只到扬州，离卦也。 玉浓炼形，自震卦为始，至离卦方止也。 直解曰：玉液，肾液也，上升到心，三气相合而过重楼，则津满玉池，谓之玉液。 若咽之，自中田而入下田，则曰还丹：若升之，自中田而入四肢，则日炼形，其实一物而已。 此系来药三百日数足胎圆，而飞金晶减一卦，勒阳关如旧，罢采药，添入咽法，咽法随四时而已。 此系炼形法，用卦后，添入炼形，自震卦为始，离卦为期，不限年月日，见验方止，体色光泽，神气秀媚，渐畏腥秽以冲口腹，凡情凡爱心境自除，真气将足而似常饱，所合不多，饮酒无量，尘骨已更而变神识，步趋走马，其行如飞，目如点漆，体若凝脂，绀发再生，皱脸重舒，老去永驻童颜，仰视百步而见秋毫，身体之间，旧痕残，自然消除，涕泪涎汗，亦不见有，圣丹生味，灵液透香，口鼻之间，常有真香奇味，漱津成酥，可以疗，人疾病，遍体皆成白膏，上件皆玉液还丹炼形之验。 见验即止，当谨节用功，依法随时，而行后事。 金液还丹第七附金液炼形 《金诰》曰：积阳成神，神中有形，形生于日，日生于月； 积阴成形，形中有神，神生于金，金生于玉。

In the three months of summer, when heart qi flourishes and lung qi is weak, the swallowing method is practiced daily under the *Xun* trigram. In the three months of autumn, when lung qi flourishes and spleen qi is weak, the swallowing method is practiced daily under the *Gen* trigram. In the three months of winter, when kidney qi flourishes and heart qi is weak, the swallowing method is practiced daily under the *Zhen* trigram. During the transitional months of the four seasons, when spleen qi flourishes and kidney qi is weak—since kidney qi is the root of human life and weakness occurs in all four seasons—during the last eighteen days of each seasonal transition, the swallowing method is practiced daily under the *Dui* trigram, used concurrently with the previous swallowing method. Only in autumn is the *Dui* trigram’s swallowing method employed exclusively, discontinuing the *Gen* trigram’s practice.

For the above swallowing methods, first follow the previous method to swallow. If no fluid is generated between the teeth and the Jade Pool, simply fill the mouth with the tongue, close the Jade Pool, draw in the jaws, and swallow emptily as the method—this refers to swallowing qi, within which water naturally arises. The number of qi-swallowings: in the first year, thirty-six to forty-nine times; in the next year, eighty-one times; and in the following year, one hundred eighty-one times, at which point verification appears—this is the method of returning the fluid to the cinnabar. The practice should not exceed three years; it irrigates the cinnabar field, bathes the fetal immortal, and true qi grows ever more abundant.

If one practices this method of returning the jade fluid to the cinnabar, after three hundred days of nurturing the inner cinnabar and true qi begins to arise, the *Gen* trigram’s flying golden essence will strike the three passes and ascend to the Mud Pill Palace. Then, the method of returning the golden fluid to the cinnabar is performed: from the crown of the head, a stream of golden water descends, flowing back to the Yellow Court, where it transforms into gold and becomes cinnabar—this is called the Golden Cinnabar.

When practicing the method of returning the golden fluid, one should be in a secluded chamber where wind, sunlight, and ordinary people do not reach. Burn incense, sit cross-legged with palms stacked, first crouching the body and then rising. As soon as the fire is felt to ignite, sit upright, extinguish all thoughts, forget all emotions, and inwardly observe. Precisely when the *Gen* trigram’s flying golden essence enters the crown, slightly raise the head and tilt the neck back, allowing the fire to fill the area beneath the neck. Then nod the head forward, lower it, and curve the neck. Retract the tongue, pressing it firmly against the upper palate, where clear and refreshing water arises, its taste sweet and fragrant. It ascends to the nape, descends through the hundred vessels, and a true fragrance is naturally detected in the nose, while an extraordinary flavor lingers on the tongue. Without rinsing, swallow it, sending it down to the Yellow Court—this is called the Golden Fluid Returning to the Cinnabar.

In spring, summer, autumn, and winter, regardless of the time, after the flying golden essence enters the brain, proceed step by step with this method, from *Gen* to *Xun* only. In the evening, the method of restraining the yang gate is practiced from *Dui* to *Qian* only. When practicing this method, one must strictly regulate conduct beyond previous standards to achieve success. Ultimately, it serves only to refine the form and abide in the world, attaining longevity without death, but not transcendence.

The *Essentials of the Dao* states: "Recognize the root and stem of the Five Phases, and you will understand spring, summer, autumn, and winter. Drink several cups of nectar, and in drunkenness wander the Moon Palace."

Explanation: "Recognize the root and stem of the Five Phases" refers to inverting the Five Phases’ mutual generation and restraint, employing different trigrams at different times to practice the swallowing method. "Understand spring, summer, autumn, and winter" means adjusting the timing accordingly. "Nectar" is the jade fluid. "Moon Palace" is the cinnabar field. "Drunkenness" refers to frequent swallowing.

"Gazing eastward at Fusang before dawn, rising behind and swallowing without cease. Galloping like a steed through the cosmos, the eldest son reaches only Yangzhou."

Explanation: "Gazing eastward at Fusang before dawn" refers to the time before sunrise, the hour of the *Gen* trigram. "Rising behind" is the flying golden essence. "Swallowing ahead" is the jade fluid returning to the cinnabar. "Galloping steed" is the ignition of fire, the jade fluid refining the form. "Wandering the cosmos" means filling the four limbs. "Eldest son" is the *Zhen* trigram. "Reaches only Yangzhou" is the *Li* trigram. Refining the form with jade fluid begins with the *Zhen* trigram and ends with the *Li* trigram.

Direct Explanation: The jade fluid is kidney fluid. When it ascends to the heart, the three qi harmonize and pass the Towering Pavilion, filling the Jade Pool—this is called jade fluid. If swallowed, it enters the lower field from the middle field, called returning cinnabar. If ascended, it enters the four limbs from the middle field, called refining the form—though in truth, it is the same substance.

This pertains to the completion of the three hundred days of gathering medicine, the perfection of the fetal cinnabar, the reduction of the flying golden essence by one trigram, the continued restraint of the yang gate, the cessation of medicine-gathering, and the addition of the swallowing method, which varies with the four seasons. This is the method of refining the form. After employing the trigrams, refining the form is added, beginning with the *Zhen* trigram and concluding with the *Li* trigram, without limit to years, months, or days—only ceasing upon verification. The body’s complexion becomes radiant, the spirit’s qi refined and elegant. Gradually, one grows averse to foul odors assaulting the mouth and stomach, worldly passions and attachments naturally dissolve, true qi becomes abundant and one feels perpetually sated, requiring little food. One can drink limitless wine, the mortal bones transform into spiritual awareness, movement is swift as a galloping horse, the eyes dark as lacquer, the body smooth as congealed fat. Azure hair regrows, wrinkled faces smooth anew, old age is forever replaced by a youthful countenance. One can see autumn down at a hundred paces. Old scars and blemishes on the body naturally vanish. Tears, saliva, and sweat no longer appear. The sacred cinnabar generates flavor, the numinous fluid exudes fragrance. Between mouth and nose, true fragrance and extraordinary flavors constantly arise. Rinsing the saliva produces a buttery substance that can heal others’ illnesses. The entire body transforms into white cream. All the above are verifications of the jade fluid returning to the cinnabar and refining the form.

Upon verification, cease practice, strictly regulate conduct, follow the method according to the season, and proceed to subsequent matters.

**Golden Fluid Returning to the Cinnabar, Seventh: Appended Method of Refining the Form with Golden Fluid**

The *Golden Edict* states: "Accumulated yang forms spirit; within spirit, there is form. Form is born of the sun; the sun is born of the moon. Accumulated yin forms the body; within the body, there is spirit. Spirit is born of metal; metal is born of jade."

chunks.original_text: 随阴阳而生没者，日月之光也，因数生光，数本于乾坤； 随阴阳而升降者，金玉之气也，因时起气，时本于天地。 《真源》曰：日月之光，旦后用九，晦前用六，六九乾坤之数； 金玉之气，春夏上升，秋冬下降，升降天地之时。 金生于玉，玉生于石，石生于土，见于形而在下者如此； 中金乌，月中玉兔，月待日魂而光，见于神而在上者如此。 《比喻》曰：日月，比气也，肾气比月，而心气比日； 金玉，比液也，肾液比金，而心液比玉。 所谓玉液者，本自肾气上升而到于心，以合心气，二气相交而过重楼，闭口不出而津满玉池，咽之而曰玉液还丹，升之而曰玉液炼形。 是液本自肾中来而生于心，亦比土中生石、石中生玉之说也。 所谓金液者，肾气合心气而不上升，熏蒸于肺，肺为华益，下罩二气，即日而取肺液，在下田自尾闾穴升上，乃曰飞金晶入脑中，以补泥丸之宫，自上复下降而入下田，乃曰金液还丹，既还下田复升，遍满四体，前复上升，乃曰金液炼形，是亦金生于土之说也。 凡欲炼形飞金晶者，当在静室中，切禁风日，遥焚香，密启三清上圣：“臣所愿长生在世，传行大道，演化告人，当先自行炼形之法，欲得不畏寒暑，绝淡谷食，逃于阴阳之外。 ”咒毕，乃咽之。 《真诀》曰：背后尾闻穴曰下关，夹脊曰中关，脑后曰上关。 始飞金晶以通三关，肾比地，心比天，上到顶以比九天。 玉液炼形，自心至顶以通九天。 三百日大药就，胎仙圆，而真气生，前起则行玉液炼形之旧道，后起则行飞金晶之旧道，金晶玉液，行功，见验，自坎卦为始，后起一升入顶，以双手微闭双耳，内观如法，微咽于津，乃以舌抵定牙关，下闭玉池，以待上腭之津下而方咽，咽毕复起，至良封为期。 春冬两起一咽，秋夏五起一咽，凡一咽数，秋夏不过五十数，春冬不过百数。 自后咽罢升身前起，以满头面、四肢、五指，气盛方止，再起再升，至离卦为期。 凡此后起咽津，乃曰金液还丹，还丹之后而复前起，乃曰金液炼形。 自艮卦之后，炼形至离卦方止，兑卦勒阳关，至乾封方止，以后起到顶，自上而下，号曰金液还丹，金丹之气前起，自下而上，号曰金液炼形，形显琪树金花。 若以金液还丹，未到下元而前后俱起，乃曰火起焚身。 此是金液还丹炼形，既前后俱起，兼了焚身。 凡行此等，切须谨节苦志而无懈怠，以见验为度也。 《道要》曰：起后终宵闭耳，随时对饮金液。 宴到青州方住，日西又听阳歌。 解曰：起后终宵闭耳者，为行金液还丹，须是肘后飞金晶，一撞三关，其气才起，急须双手闭耳，耳是肾波之门，恐泄肾气于外，而不入脑中也。 随时对钦金波者，既觉气入脑中，即便依前法，点头曲项，退舌尖近抵上腭，请甘之水，有奇异之验，甘若蜜味之甜也。 当艮卦飞金晶一咽，至震卦方止。 青州，震卦也。 日西，兑卦也。 又听阳歌者，自兑势勒阳关，直到乾卦，不必采药也。 饮罢终宵火起，前升后举焚身。 虽是不拘年月，日中自有乾 解曰：此一诀是金液炼形之法也。 饮罢终宵火起者，依前法金液还丹； ”而艮卦炼形是起火也。 前升后举，飞金晶而起火也。 凡玉液炼形之法，先后起金晶入顶，次还丹而复前升之以炼形，是比金液炼形之法不同也。

That which arises and vanishes with yin and yang is the light of the sun and moon, for light is born of number, and number originates in Qian and Kun. That which ascends and descends with yin and yang is the qi of metal and jade, for qi arises with the seasons, and the seasons originate in Heaven and Earth.

*The True Source* states: "The light of the sun and moon: after dawn, use nine; before the dark of the moon, use six. Six and nine are the numbers of Qian and Kun. The qi of metal and jade: in spring and summer, it ascends; in autumn and winter, it descends. Ascending and descending are the seasons of Heaven and Earth. Metal is born of jade, jade of stone, stone of earth—thus are those seen in form and below. Within the sun is the Golden Crow; within the moon, the Jade Hare. The moon awaits the sun’s soul to shine—thus are those seen in spirit and above."

*The Analogy* states: "The sun and moon are likened to qi: kidney qi is likened to the moon, and heart qi to the sun. Metal and jade are likened to fluid: kidney fluid is likened to metal, and heart fluid to jade. The so-called *jade fluid* originally ascends from kidney qi to the heart, uniting with heart qi. The two qi merge and pass the *Double Towers*, the mouth is closed so that saliva fills the *Jade Pool*, and when swallowed, it is called *jade fluid returning to the cinnabar*; when ascended, it is called *refining the form with jade fluid*. This fluid, born in the heart yet originating from the kidneys, is analogous to the saying that jade is born of stone, and stone of earth.

The so-called *golden fluid*: kidney qi unites with heart qi but does not ascend, instead steaming the lungs. The lungs, as the *Flower Canopy*, enshroud the two qi. Drawing lung fluid at midday, it ascends from the *Lower Field* through the *Weilü* cavity, called *flying golden essence into the brain* to replenish the *Mud Pill Palace*. From above, it descends again into the *Lower Field*, called *golden fluid returning to the cinnabar*. Once returned, it ascends again, filling the four limbs, then rises once more—this is called *refining the form with golden fluid*, which is also the saying that metal is born of earth.

For those who wish to refine the form and fly golden essence, they must remain in a quiet chamber, strictly avoiding wind and sunlight. From afar, they burn incense and secretly invoke the Three Pure Ones and Supreme Sages: *'Your disciple wishes for longevity in this world, to transmit and practice the Great Dao, to teach and transform others. First, I must personally practice the method of refining the form, to become untouched by cold or heat, to transcend grain and fasting, and to escape beyond yin and yang.'* After the incantation, they swallow the fluid.

*The True Formula* states: "Behind the back, the *Weilü* cavity is called the *Lower Pass*; beside the spine is the *Middle Pass*; behind the brain is the *Upper Pass*. First, fly the golden essence to open the Three Passes. The kidneys are likened to earth, the heart to heaven, and ascending to the crown is likened to the Nine Heavens. Refining the form with jade fluid ascends from the heart to the crown, opening the Nine Heavens.

After three hundred days, the great medicine is complete, the fetal immortal is perfected, and true qi is born. When rising from the front, follow the old path of refining the form with jade fluid; when rising from the back, follow the old path of flying golden essence. As golden essence and jade fluid circulate, verification appears, beginning with the *Kan* trigram. After rising once to the crown, gently close both ears with the hands, inwardly observe as prescribed, and subtly swallow the saliva. Press the tongue firmly against the teeth, close the *Jade Pool* below, and wait for the fluid from the upper palate to descend before swallowing. After swallowing, rise again, with *Liangfeng* as the limit. In spring and winter, rise twice and swallow once; in autumn and summer, rise five times and swallow once. In each swallowing count, autumn and summer do not exceed fifty, and spring and winter do not exceed one hundred.

After swallowing, rise from the front of the body, filling the head, face, four limbs, and five fingers until the qi is abundant, then stop. Rise and ascend again, with *Li* as the limit. After this, rising from the back to swallow saliva is called *golden fluid returning to the cinnabar*; after returning, rising from the front is called *refining the form with golden fluid*. From the *Gen* trigram onward, refining the form continues until the *Li* trigram, then restrains the *Yang Pass* at *Dui* until *Qian* is sealed. After rising from the back to the crown, descending from above is called *golden fluid returning to the cinnabar*; the qi of the golden elixir rising from the front, ascending from below, is called *refining the form with golden fluid*, manifesting as jade trees and golden flowers.

If, in *golden fluid returning to the cinnabar*, the ascent has not yet reached the *Lower Origin* but rises from both front and back, it is called *fire rising to burn the body*. This is *golden fluid returning to the cinnabar and refining the form*, where both front and back rise together, completing the burning of the body. In practicing this, one must strictly regulate conduct, endure hardship, and remain unwavering until verification is achieved.

*The Essentials of the Dao* states: "After rising, close the ears all night and drink golden fluid in due time. The feast reaches Qingzhou before stopping; at sunset, listen again to the yang song." The explanation: "After rising, close the ears all night" refers to practicing *golden fluid returning to the cinnabar*, where one must fly golden essence from behind the elbow, striking the Three Passes. As soon as the qi rises, quickly close both ears with the hands, for the ears are the gates of kidney qi, preventing its leakage outward so it does not enter the brain. "Drink golden fluid in due time" means that once the qi enters the brain, immediately follow the previous method: nod the head, curve the neck, retract the tongue so its tip nearly touches the upper palate, and invite the sweet water, which has an extraordinary effect, as sweet as honey. At the *Gen* trigram, fly golden essence once and swallow until the *Zhen* trigram. Qingzhou is the *Zhen* trigram. Sunset is the *Dui* trigram. "Listen again to the yang song" means that from the *Dui* trigram, restrain the *Yang Pass* until the *Qian* trigram, without needing to gather the medicine.

After drinking all night, fire rises, ascending from the front and rising from the back to burn the body. Though not bound by years or months, within the day there is naturally *Qian*. The explanation: This formula is the method of *refining the form with golden fluid*. "After drinking all night, fire rises" refers to *golden fluid returning to the cinnabar* as before; refining the form at the *Gen* trigram is the rising of fire. Ascending from the front and rising from the back is flying golden essence to ignite the fire. The method of refining the form with jade fluid first rises from the back, flying golden essence into the crown, then returns the elixir and rises again from the front to refine the form—this differs from the method of refining the form with golden fluid."

**Chapter Eight: Refining Qi to Align with the Origin**

The *Golden Edict* states: When the primordial qi first divided, the Great Dao took form and established the binary patterns of yin and yang. Once yin and yang settled into their positions, the Great Dao acquired names and divided into the Five Emperors. The Five Emperors rule different lands, each guarding one direction; the five directions possess distinct qi, each governed by a child.

The child of the Green Emperor receives *jia* and *yi*, the nine qi of Heaven’s true Wood virtue.
The child of the Red Emperor receives *bing* and *ding*, the three qi of Heaven’s true Fire virtue.
The child of the White Emperor receives *geng* and *xin*, the seven qi of Heaven’s true Metal virtue.
The child of the Black Emperor receives *ren* and *gui*, the five qi of Heaven’s true Water virtue.
The child of the Yellow Emperor receives *wu* and *ji*, the one qi of Heaven’s true Earth virtue.

From the one qi, True Unity is born. True Unity emerges through Earth, thus all things are generated in Earth, and the Five Phases are generated in the One. The Dao of the True Origin is born from the one qi.

The *Jade Book* states: One, three, five, seven, nine—these are the divisions of the Dao into numbers.
Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth—these are the transformations of the Dao into images.
East, West, South, North, Center—these are the arrangements of the Dao into positions.
Green, White, Red, Yellow, Black—these are the dispersals of the Dao into substances.

Numbers return to the absence of numbers; images revert to the absence of images; positions dissolve into the absence of positions; substances resolve into the absence of substances.

To attain the Dao’s absence of numbers, do not divide—then there are no numbers.
To attain the Dao’s absence of images, do not transform—then there are no images.
To attain the Dao’s absence of positions, do not arrange—then there are no positions.
To attain the Dao’s absence of substances, do not disperse—then there are no substances.

The absence of numbers is the Dao’s source.
The absence of images is the Dao’s root.
The absence of positions is the Dao’s truth.
The absence of substances is the Dao’s subtlety.

The *True Source* states: Once the Dao’s source divided, it descended from the root and flowed to the branches. Those who awaken to its truth cultivate truth through truth; inner truth naturally manifests externally. Those who recognize its subtlety create subtlety through subtlety; inner subtlety naturally manifests externally.

Heaven and Earth attain the Dao’s truth, yet their truth remains unmanifest—thus they are not free from positions.
Heaven and Earth attain the Dao’s subtlety, yet their subtlety remains unmanifest—thus they are not free from substances.
With substances, there are images to seek; with positions, there are numbers to deduce.

Among all things between Heaven and Earth, none is more noble than humanity. Just as Heaven and Earth possess images to seek, one knows their substances and qi are like water. Just as Heaven and Earth possess numbers to deduce, one knows their positions are near or far. Examining this closely, the Dao is not distant from humanity.

The *Analogy* states: Heaven and Earth have the Five Emperors, just as humans have the five viscera.
The Green Emperor’s *jia* and *yi* (Wood), *jia* as yang and *yi* as yin, correspond to the liver’s qi and fluids.
The Black Emperor’s *ren* and *gui* (Water), *ren* as yang and *gui* as yin, correspond to the kidneys’ qi and fluids.
The Yellow Emperor’s *wu* and *ji* (Earth), *wu* as yang and *ji* as yin, correspond to the spleen’s qi and fluids.
The Red Emperor’s *bing* and *ding* (Fire), *bing* as yang and *ding* as yin, correspond to the heart’s qi and fluids.

chunks.original_text: 大道本无用，运于物也，其深莫测，无理可究。 以体言道，道始有外内之辨； 以用言道，道始有观见之基。 观乎内而不观乎外，外无不究而内得明矣，观乎神而不观乎形，形无不备而神得见矣。 《真源》曰，以一心观万物，万物不谓之有徐； 以万物挠一气，一气不谓之不足。 一气归一心，心不可为物之所夺； 一心运一气，气不可为法之所役。 心源清彻，照万破，亦不知有物也； 气战刚强，万感一息，亦不知有法也。 物物无物，以还本来之象； 法法无法，乃全自得之真。 《比喻》曰：以象生形，因形立名。 有名则推其数，有数则得其理。 盖高上虚无，无物可喻，所可比者，如人之修炼，节序无差，成就有次，冲和之气，凝而不散，至虚真性，恬淡无为，神合乎道，归于自然。 当此之际，以无心为心，如何谓之应物以无物为物，如何谓之用法？ 真乐熙熙，不知己之有身，渐入无为之道，以入希夷之域，斯为入圣超凡之客。 《真诀》曰：此法合道，有如常说存想之理，又如禅僧入定之时，当择福地置室，跪礼焚香，正坐盘膝，散发披衣，握固存神，冥心闭目，午时前微微升身，起火炼炁，午时后微微敛身，聚火炼丹，不拘昼夜，神清气合，自然喜悦。 坐中或闻声莫听，见境勿认，物境自散，若认物境，转加魔障。 魔障不迟，急急向前，以身微敛，敛而伸腰，后以胸微幅，偃不伸腰，少时前后火起，高升其勿动，名曰焚身，火起魔障自散于躯外，阴邪不入于壳中。 如此三两次已，当想遍天地之间，皆是炎炎之火，火毕清凉，了无一物，但见车马歌舞，轩盖绣罗，富贵繁华，人物欢娱，成队成行，五色云升，如登天界，及到彼中，又见楼台耸翠，院字徘徊，珍珠金玉，满地不收，花果池亭，莫知其数，须臾异香四起，妓乐之音，嘈嘈杂杂，宾朋满坐，水陆陈，且笑且语，共贺太平，珍玩之物，互相献受，当此之际； 虽然不是阴鬼魔军，亦不得认为好事。 益修真之人，弃绝外事，甘受寂寞，或潜迹江湖之地，或遁身隐僻之隅，绝念忘情，举动有戒，久受劬劳，而历潇洒，一旦功成法立，遍见如此繁华； 又不谓是明魔，格谓实到天宫，殊不知脱凡胎，在顶中自己天宫之内； 因而贪恋，认为实境，不用超脱之法，止于身中，阳神不出，而胎仙不化； 乃曰出昏衢之上，为陆地神仙，仅可长生不死而已，不能脱质升仙，而归三岛，以作仙子，到此可惜！ 学人自当虑超脱虽难，不可不行也。 《道要》曰：不无尽法已减省故也。 超脱分形第十 《金诰》曰：道本无也，以有言者，非道也； 道本虚也，以实言者，非道也； 既为无体，则问应俱不能矣； 朗为无象，则视听俱不能矣。 以玄微为道； 玄微亦不离问答之累； 以希夷为道，希宪亦未免视听之累。 希夷玄微尚未为道，则道亦不知其所以然也。 《玉书》曰：其来有始，而不知大道之始，何也其去有尽，而不知大道之终； 何也？ 高高之上虽有上，而不知大道之上无有穷也深深之下虽有下，而不知大道之下无有极也。 杏杏莫测名曰道，随物所得而列等殊，无为之道，莫能穷究也。 《真诀》曰：超者，超出凡躯而入圣品； 脱者，脱去俗胎而为仙子； 是神入气胎，气全真性，须是前功节节见验正当，方居清静之室；

The great Dao has no function; it operates through things. Its depth is unfathomable, and no principle can exhaust it. Speaking of the Dao in terms of its essence, distinctions between external and internal arise; speaking of it in terms of its function, the foundation for observation and perception is established. Observe the internal and not the external, and though nothing external remains unexamined, the internal becomes clear. Observe the spirit and not the form, and though no form is left unprepared, the spirit becomes visible.

*The True Source* states: With one mind, observe the myriad things, and the myriad things cannot be said to be excessive. With the myriad things disturbing the one qi, the one qi cannot be said to be insufficient. When the one qi returns to the one mind, the mind cannot be seized by things. When the one mind moves the one qi, the qi cannot be enslaved by methods. When the source of the mind is pure and clear, it illuminates the ten thousand and shatters them, yet remains unaware of things. When qi wages a fierce struggle, the ten thousand sensations rest in a single breath, yet remain unaware of methods. Things are no-things, returning to the original image; methods are no-methods, thus fulfilling the true self-attainment.

*The Parable* states: From images arise forms, and from forms names are established. With names, one infers their numbers; with numbers, one grasps their principles. Yet the lofty and supreme void is such that nothing can compare to it. What can be likened to it is like a person’s cultivation: the sequence of stages is unerring, and attainment follows order. The harmonious qi congeals without dispersing; the utterly empty true nature is serene and without action. The spirit merges with the Dao and returns to spontaneity. At this moment, with no-mind as mind, how can one speak of responding to things? With no-thing as thing, how can one speak of employing methods? In true joy, radiant and blissful, one forgets the existence of one’s own body. Gradually entering the Dao of non-action, one reaches the realm of the subtle and imperceptible, becoming a guest who has entered sagehood and transcended the ordinary.

*The True Formula* states: This method accords with the Dao, resembling the principle of visualization often discussed, or like the moment when a Chan monk enters samadhi. One should choose an auspicious site and prepare a chamber, kneel in reverence, burn incense, sit upright with legs crossed, let the hair down and the robe loose, clasp the hands to retain spirit, quiet the mind, and close the eyes. Before noon, slightly raise the body to kindle the fire and refine qi; after noon, slightly gather the body to concentrate the fire and refine the elixir. Regardless of day or night, when spirit and qi harmonize, joy arises naturally. During meditation, if sounds are heard, do not listen; if visions appear, do not acknowledge them. External phenomena will disperse on their own; if one acknowledges them, demonic obstacles will only intensify. When demonic obstacles arise without delay, swiftly proceed forward: slightly gather the body, then straighten the waist; afterward, slightly arch the chest, lean back without straightening the waist. After a short while, fire will rise before and behind—do not move when it ascends, for this is called "firing the body." When the fire rises, demonic obstacles will scatter beyond the body, and yin evil will not enter the shell. After two or three repetitions, visualize all between heaven and earth as raging flames. When the fire subsides, all is cool and clear, with nothing remaining—only carriages and horses, singing and dancing, canopies and embroidered silks, wealth and splendor, joyous figures in processions, ascending on five-colored clouds as if entering the celestial realm. Upon arrival, one sees towering pavilions and jade-green terraces, courtyards and corridors, pearls and gold scattered ungathered, gardens and ponds, flowers and fruits beyond count. Suddenly, exotic fragrances arise on all sides, and the sounds of music and revelry fill the air. Guests and friends sit in abundance, with delicacies of land and sea laid out. Laughing and conversing, they celebrate great peace, exchanging rare treasures. At this moment, though these are not the armies of yin ghosts or demons, one must not regard them as auspicious events.

For those who cultivate the true, who abandon worldly affairs and willingly endure solitude—whether concealing themselves in rivers and lakes or secluding themselves in remote corners, cutting off thoughts and forgetting emotions, every action guarded—after long toil and hardship, once the work is accomplished and the method established, such splendor may appear. Yet if one does not recognize this as a manifestation of demons but instead believes it to be the true celestial palace, unaware that having shed the mortal coil, one’s own celestial palace lies within the crown—if one becomes attached and takes it as reality, failing to employ the method of transcendence, remaining within the body, the yang spirit will not emerge, and the immortal embryo will not transform—then one may claim to have risen above the dark paths, becoming a terrestrial immortal, merely achieving longevity without death. Yet one cannot shed the physical form to ascend as an immortal and return to the Three Isles as a transcendent being. At this point, what a pity! Students must consider that though transcendence is difficult, it cannot be neglected.

*The Essentials of the Dao* states: It is not that the inexhaustible method has diminished.

**Transcendence and Liberation of Form, Tenth Chapter**

*The Golden Teachings* states: The Dao is originally nothing; to speak of it as existing is not the Dao. The Dao is originally empty; to speak of it as substantial is not the Dao. Since it is without form, neither questioning nor response can reach it. Since it is without image, neither sight nor hearing can grasp it. If one takes the mysterious and subtle as the Dao, the mysterious and subtle still cannot escape the burden of question and answer. If one takes the subtle and imperceptible as the Dao, the subtle and imperceptible still cannot avoid the burden of sight and hearing. If even the subtle and imperceptible are not the Dao, then the Dao is also beyond knowing how it is so.

*The Jade Scripture* states: Its coming has a beginning, yet one does not know the beginning of the great Dao. What is this? Its going has an end, yet one does not know the end of the great Dao. What is this? Above the loftiest height, though there is still higher, one does not know that above the great Dao there is no limit. Below the deepest depth, though there is still lower, one does not know that below the great Dao there is no end. Vast and unfathomable, it is called the Dao. It accords with what things attain and arranges them in differing ranks. The Dao of non-action cannot be exhausted.

*The True Formula* states: "Transcend" means transcending the mortal frame to enter sagehood; "liberate" means shedding the mundane embryo to become an immortal child. It is when the spirit enters the qi embryo, qi is complete, and true nature is realized—only when each stage of prior effort has been verified and is correct—should one reside in a chamber of purity.

chunks.original_text: 以入希夷之境，内观认阳神，次起火降魔，焚身聚气，真气升在天宫，壳中清静，了无一物。 当择幽居，一依内观，三礼既毕，平身不须高升，正坐不须敛伸，闭目冥心，静极朝元之后，身躯如在空中，神气飘然，难为制御，默然内观，明朗不昧，山川秀丽，楼阁依稀，紫气红光，纷纭为陈，祥鸾彩凤，音语如簧，异景盟华，可谓壶中真趣，而洞天别景，追逐自在，冥然不知有尘世之累，是真空之际，其气自转，不须用法依时。 若见青气出东方，笙簧嘹亮，旌节车马，左右前后，不知多少，须臾南方赤气出，西方白气出，北方黑气出，中央黄气出，五气结聚而为彩云，乐声嘈杂，喜气熙熙，金童玉女，扶拥自身，或跨火龙，或乘玄鹤，或路彩鸾，或骑猛虎，升腾空中，自上而下。 所过之处，楼台现宇，不能尽陈，神抵官吏，不可备说，又到一处，女乐万行，宫撩班列，如人间帝王之仪，圣贤毕至，当此之时，见之傍若无人，乘驾上升，以至一门，兵卫严肃，而不可犯，左右前后，官僚女乐，留恋不已，终是过门不得，轩盖覆面，自上而下，复入旧居之地，如此上，不厌其数，是调神出壳之法也。 积日纯熟，一升而到天宫，一降而还旧处，上下绝无碍滞，乃自下而上，或如登七级宝塔，或如上三层琼楼，其始也’‘级而复一级，七级上尽，以至顶中，辄不得下视，恐神惊而恋躯不出，既至七级之上，则闭目便跳，如寐如脂，身外有身，形如婴儿，肌肤鲜洁，神采莹然，回视故躯，亦不见有，所见之者，乃如粪堆，又如枯木，憎愧万端，辄不可顿弃而远游。 益其神出未熟，圣气凝结而成，须是再入本躯，往来出入，一任遨游，始乎一步二步，次二里三里，积日纯熟，乃如壮士展臂，可千里万里，而形神壮大，勇气坚固，然后寄凡骸于名山大州之中，从往来应世之外，不与俗类等伦，或行满而受天书，骖鸾乘凤，跨虎骑龙，自东自西，以入紫府，先见太微真君，次居下岛，欲升洞天，当传道积行于人问，受天书而升洞天，以为天仙。 凡行此法，古今少有成者，益以功不备而欲行之速，便为此道； 或功验未证，止事静坐，欲求超脱； 或阴灵不散，出为鬼仙，人不见形，来往去任，终无所归，止于投胎就舍，而夺人躯壳，复得为人； 或出入不熟，往来无法，一去一来，无由再入本躯，神魂不知所在，乃释子之坐化、道流之尸解也。 故行此道，要在前功见验正当仍择地筑室，以远一切腥秽之物、臭恶之气、往来之声、女子之色，不止于触其真气，而神亦厌之。 既出而复入，入而不出，则形神俱妙，与天地齐年，而浩劫不死； 既入而复出，出而不入，如蝉脱蜕，迁神入圣，此乃超凡脱俗，以为真人仙子，而在风尘之外，寄居三岛十洲者也。 《道要》曰：不无尽法已灭息矣。 右大乘三门，系天仙。

Entering the realm of the formless and soundless, one inwardly observes and recognizes the yang spirit. Next, one kindles the fire to subdue demons, burns the body to gather qi, and the true qi ascends to the celestial palace. Within the shell, all is serene—utterly devoid of anything. One must choose a secluded dwelling and rely solely on inward contemplation. After the three bows are completed, sit upright without rising, the body settled without need for stretching or contracting. Close the eyes, still the mind, and after profound tranquility reaches its apex, the body seems suspended in emptiness, the spirit and qi drifting freely, difficult to restrain. Silently turn the gaze inward, and all becomes luminous and unobscured: mountains and rivers appear resplendent, pavilions and terraces faintly discernible. Purple qi and crimson radiance swirl in profusion; auspicious simurghs and rainbow-feathered phoenixes sing with voices like reed pipes. Wondrous visions and resplendent scenes—this is the true delight within the alchemical crucible, the distinct landscape of the grotto-heaven. One roams at will, oblivious to the burdens of the dusty world. At this moment of true emptiness, the qi circulates of itself, without need for method or adherence to time.

If a green qi emerges from the east, accompanied by the bright strains of reed pipes and drums, with banners, chariots, and attendants—uncountable in number—appearing on all sides, soon a red qi arises from the south, a white qi from the west, a black qi from the north, and a yellow qi from the center. The five qi converge to form iridescent clouds, while music resounds in joyful tumult. Jade maidens and golden youths surround and support one’s body, some riding fiery dragons, some mounting black cranes, some journeying on rainbow phoenixes, some astride fierce tigers. Ascending into the void, they descend from above. Wherever they pass, towers and palaces manifest, too numerous to recount; divine officials and immortals appear, beyond full description. Arriving at another place, ten thousand ranks of female musicians stand in ordered rows, like the courtly procession of an earthly emperor. Sages and worthies gather in full assembly. At this moment, one remains unmoved by all around, ascending in one’s chariot until reaching a gate. The guards stand in solemn array, unapproachable. On all sides, officials, attendants, and musicians linger in reluctance, yet one ultimately passes through the gate without hindrance. The canopy of the chariot veils the face as one descends from above, returning to the former dwelling. Such ascents occur repeatedly, without number—this is the method of refining the spirit to exit the shell.

With days of accumulation and mastery, one ascends in a single motion to the celestial palace and descends in one motion to the original abode, moving up and down without the slightest obstruction. Then, ascending from below, one may climb a seven-tiered jeweled pagoda or ascend a three-story jade tower. At first, step by step, one climbs the seven tiers to the summit, yet must not look downward, lest the spirit be startled and cling to the body, failing to emerge. Once atop the seventh tier, close the eyes and leap as if in slumber or trance. A body exists outside the body, its form like that of an infant, its skin fresh and radiant, its spirit luminous. Looking back at the former shell, one sees nothing—only what resembles a dung heap or a withered tree. Shame and revulsion arise in full measure, yet one cannot immediately abandon it and wander afar. For the spirit’s exit is not yet perfected, and the sagely qi has congealed into form. One must re-enter the original body, coming and going freely, roaming at will. At first, one step, then two; then two leagues, then three. With days of accumulation and mastery, one moves like a warrior extending an arm—able to traverse a thousand or ten thousand leagues. The form and spirit grow robust, the courage steadfast. Then, one may entrust the mortal frame to a famous mountain or sacred realm, dwelling beyond the world of transient appearances, no longer equated with the vulgar. When merit is complete, one receives the celestial writ, rides simurghs and phoenixes, mounts tigers and dragons, journeying east and west to enter the Purple Palace. First, one meets the True Lord of the Grand Tenuity, then resides on the lower isles. To ascend to the grotto-heaven, one must transmit the Dao and accumulate merit among mortals, receive the celestial writ, and rise to the grotto-heaven as a celestial immortal.

Few in ancient or modern times have succeeded in this practice, for most seek to hasten the process before their merit is complete, or attempt this path prematurely. Some, though their merit remains unverified, merely engage in quiet sitting, hoping for transcendence. Others, with unresolved yin spirits, become ghost immortals—unseen in form, wandering at will, yet ultimately without refuge, forced to seize mortal bodies and be reborn as humans. Some, unskilled in exit and entry, lack the method for return; once departed, they cannot re-enter their original body, and their spirit drifts without destination—this is the "sitting transformation" of Buddhist monks or the "corpse liberation" of Daoist adepts. Thus, in pursuing this path, one must ensure that prior merit is verified and correct, and choose a site to construct a chamber, far from all foul and putrid substances, noxious vapors, passing sounds, and the allure of women—lest they disturb the true qi and repulse the spirit.

If one exits and re-enters, enters and does not exit, then form and spirit attain perfection, matching the years of heaven and earth, enduring through eons without death. If one enters and then exits without re-entering, it is like the cicada shedding its husk—shifting the spirit to sagehood. This is transcending the mortal and shedding the mundane, becoming a true person and immortal child, dwelling beyond the dusty world, residing on the Three Isles and Ten Continents.

*The Essentials of the Dao* states: "The dharma of non-extinction has already ceased."

The above pertains to the three gates of the Great Vehicle, belonging to the celestial immortals.
